titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Focus Gallery Records, 1963-1987, in the Archives of American Art AAA.focugall
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Valerie Vanden Bossche

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-12-02T12:00-0500

did.abstract: The records of San Francisco Focus Gallery measure 11.8 linear feet and date from 1963-1987. The bulk of the collection consists of exhibition files. There are also artists files, sales information, correspondence, and scattered records of the gallery’s companion bookshop.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 8 series.

list.item: Series 5: Financial and Legal Files, 1966-1987 (Box 11; 0 .2 linear feet)
Series 6: Sales and Inventories, 1966-1987 (Box 11; 0.4 linear feet)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Focus Gallery was founded by Helen Head Johnson (1916-1989) in 1966 on Union Street in San Francisco. The gallery exhibited and sold primarily art photographs and other contemporary art.

Helen Head Johnston believed that photography deserved its own exhibition space. As stated in the gallery’s first press release, “in seeking to encourage print collecting it (the gallery) offers not only a show place but also a market place for photographers.” While retaining an emphasis on Bay Area photographers, the gallery's exhibitions soon became international in scope, featuring little known and well-established photographers through both solo and group exhibitions. With few exceptions, the gallery's policy was to feature an artist only once. To help keep the gallery going in its early days, Johnston started a bookshop mail-order business. At the time of its closing in August 1985, Focus Gallery was the longest continuously operating photography gallery in the country. The bookshop continued in another location for an additional two years.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Focus Gallery records are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The Focus Gallery records were donated by the estate of owner Helen Johnston, care of Gerald O’Conner, executor.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Focus Gallery records, 1963-1987. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was processed and a finding aid created by Valerie Vanden Bossche in 2013 with funding provided by the Smithsonian Institution Collections Care and Preservation Fund.

The Archives of American Art has implemented minimal processing tactics when possible in order to increase information about and access to more of our collections. Minimal processing included arrangement to the series and folder levels. Generally items within folders were simply verified with folder titles, but not arranged further. Folders within boxes may not be numbered. The collection was rehoused in archival containers and folders, but not all staples and clips were removed.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Among the holding of the Archives of American Art is an untranscribed interview of Helen Johnston by Louise Katzman or Irene Borger in the collection Interviews of California Photographers 1981 Jun.-Nov.20.
Helen Johnston left her private photography collection to the de Saisset Museum, the Oakland Museum of California, and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The records of San Francisco's Focus Gallery measure 11.8 linear feet and date from 1963-1987. The bulk of the collection consists of exhibition files. There are also artists files, sales information, correspondence, and scattered records of the gallery’s companion bookshop.

Exhibition files comprise the bulk of the collection and generally contain a wide range of materials including correspondence, short biographies, forms requesting artists’ background information, flyers, booklets, brochures, checklists, loan agreements, sales records, news releases, and photographs and negatives. Among the many photographers exhibited were Ansel Adams, Berenice Abbott, Bill Brandt, Wynn Bullock, Paul Caponigro, Imogen Cunningham, Judy Dater, Robert Heinecken, Eikoh Hosoe, Annie Leibovitz, Eliot Porter, Aaron Siskind, Jerry Uelsmann, and Brett Weston.

A relatively small amount of general business correspondence includes orders and payments for photographic prints, books, and magazine subscriptions, some personal notes, and requests for information about how to submit for exhibitions and for exhibition schedules. Correspondents include customers, photographers, publishers, law firms, museum, and colleges and universities. Correspondence from the founding year contains Johnston’s letters to various venues prominent in art photography, such as George Eastman House. There is also a letter to Ansel Adams requesting prints to sell or for a small opening exhibit.

Additional records include artists’ files; sales and inventory records containing print and bookshop inventories, general pricing information and receipts for photographs; and printed materials including flyers and brochures, bookshop catalogs and news releases. There are also scattered administrative records, including gallery history, a file on the Toren Gallery and five owner’s notebooks, as well as The Imogen Cunningham Trust files documenting Focus Gallery's interactions with the trust before and after Cunningham’s death regarding photographs printed and signed by her; financial and legal files; and guest books.
Documents in the collection that pre-date the founding of the gallery are found in the Toren Gallery file and a few of the exhibition files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Administrative records contain a gallery history file, a chronology of exhibits, owner Helen Johnston’s notebooks, a folder on Toren Gallery (founded by Robert Toren and also located in San Francisco), Imogen Cunningham Trust files regarding orders and sales of personally printed and signed photographs, and a polices and procedures file. The gallery history contains notes, press releases, and clippings, including a five year anniversary interview with Helen Johnston. This folder also has photographs, contact sheets and negatives of Ms. Johnston and the gallery. It appears that Robert Toren was a personal friend of Helen Johnston and sometimes gave her recommendations for photographers and exhibitions.

did.unittitle: Imogen Cunningham Trust Invoices, Consignment Argreements, Printed Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains general business correspondence between owner Helen Johnston and customers, photographers, publishers, law firms, museums, and colleges and universities; some with enclosures such as photographs and brochures. Topics covered include orders and payments, and inquiries about the gallery and its exhibits. Additional correspondence may be found in Series 3: Exhibition files and Series 4: Artists files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Series 1 is arranged in two subseries, Subseries 3.1: Solo Exhibition files and Subseries 3.2: Group Exhibition files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Exhibition files include flyers and brochures, biographical materials, news clippings, correspondence, and sample photographs, slides and negatives. They may also include information on exhibition layouts, lists of photographs to be included, and wall text. Among photographers exhibited were Ansel Adams, Wynn Bullock, Imogen Cunningham, Judy Dater, Aaron Siskind, Jerry Uelsmann, and Brett Weston. The file on Willard Worden (1868-1946) contains photocopies of his military service records dating from 1898 to 1946.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Folders are arranged alphabetically by photographer's last name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Artists files contain collected materials about photographers of interest who did not exhibit at the Gallery. Files contain primarily printed materials, but there are also biographical materials, correspondence, and some sample photographs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Folders are arranged alphabetically by type of material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contain bookshop, general accounting and insurance records, general business invoices and receipts, leases, and tax documents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes customer index cards, inventories and price lists of both prints and books, and receipts for photographs bought, sold, and on consignment.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Folders are arranged alphabetically, then chronologically

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains news clippings, press releases of Focus Gallery and other galleries, and Focus Gallery’s bookshop catalogs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These bound volumes and loose pages contain names, addresses, and sometimes comments, of visitors to Focus Gallery.
